comments.text:
How I make matcha as a blind person 🍵 do you have an easier way? Let me know 

Video description:
Lucy starts the video with two mugs, a wooden matcha whisk, milk and a packet of Naoki matcha. She starts by putting a teaspoon of matcha into one of the mugs, and pours a small amount of hot water into the mug (just enough to dissolve the matcha) - she then puts the matcha whisk to the side and pulls out a handheld blender. She then pours the milk into the second mug almost to the top. She puts that in her talking microwave. Once that’s out she pours the matcha mix into the milk and stirs.
comments.author: @lucyedwards

comments.text: Your real life "teehee" is so adorable
comments.author: @ElloLoJo

comments.text: I love the black Santa mug
comments.author: @Sk8rToon

comments.text: Love your yellow outfit, matches your personality so much! (Hello from Hong Kong)
comments.author: @kat39422

comments.text: I don't care for matcha, but it looks lovely. 😊 And I do think your microwave is REALLY REALLY cool.
comments.author: @StormyNichole

comments.text: Most of us Americans still have all our Christmas lights up because America is on fire and simultaneously covered in snow
comments.author: @neurodivergentpixi6736

comments.text: I'm sorry, emulsion blender has to be a joke. You're telling me you have the correct whisk, which has been used for millenia to be improved into the perfect tool for exactly the purpose you need it for, but prefer to use instead the thing that is impossible to clean and doesn't work as well? Also boiling water is not good for matcha, you're burning it which turns the sweetness into bitterness - I suppose that's fine since you just add artificial sweetness and smother it with milk 😂 but matcha is particularly sensitive to heat, it needs about 75°C
comments.author: @ScoptOriginal

comments.author: @kat39422

comments.text: Awesome 💯💯💯💯💯
comments.author: @vjhtyy7320

comments.text: just wanted to offer an alternative in the comments. Obviously this is totally valid as an easier way of making the drink, especially if you're limited on time. For me, as a totally blind person myself, I would rather use a hob. And I'd use a normal kettle, hob and microwave. My induction hob has dials that click, so I know which numbers they're on, and the rings are marked with silicon things called pan-pickles. The microwave has things called bump-ons (rubber stickers) which I ask a sighted person to put over the buttons. For me, I prefer to use equipment that isn't specialised, but that has adaptions that I or the sighted people in my life can do quickly and cheaply. Not saying one way is better, but I find that sometimes people assume blind people can't use equipment unless it talks, so thought I'd clarify. :)
comments.author: @Lyd_2006

comments.text: I'm sorry, emulsion blender has to be a joke. You're telling me you have the correct whisk, which has been used for millenia to be improved into the perfect tool for exactly the purpose you need it for, but prefer to use instead the thing that is impossible to clean and doesn't work as well? Also boiling water is not good for matcha, you're burning it which turns the sweetness into bitterness - I suppose that's fine since you just add artificial sweetness and smother it with milk 😂 but matcha is particularly sensitive to heat, it needs about 75°C
comments.author: @ScoptOriginal

comments.text:
The immersion blender is such a good idea, and it saves spending money on another single-task appliance like a milk frother if you already have something that can do that job, plus lots of others!

The small bamboo whisks might be traditional, but they also take a while, so I agree that they might be best saved for fancy tea ceremonies rather than every time you feel like a nice cuppa 😂.
comments.author: @lizhart81

For me, I prefer to use equipment that isn't specialised, but that has adaptions that I or the sighted people in my life can do quickly and cheaply. For me, as a totally blind person myself, I would rather use a hob. And I'd use a normal kettle, hob and microwave. My induction hob has dials that click, so I know which numbers they're on, and the rings are marked with silicon things called pan-pickles. The microwave has things called bump-ons (rubber stickers) which I ask a sighted person to put over the buttons. For me, I prefer to use equipment that isn't specialised, but that has adaptions that I or the sighted people in my life can do quickly and cheaply. Not saying one way is better, but I find that sometimes people assume blind people can't use equipment unless it talks, so thought I'd clarify. :)
